title: How to write your own opinion in an essay without saying “I” - Quora

response.answer_text: Easy peesy. Here are opinions stated using “I”: “I think that taxes are too high.”“I feel that people should read more books.”“I believe chimpanzees might be capable of driving cars.”Here are the same versions without “I”: “Taxes are too high.”“People should read more books.”“Chimpanzees might be capable of driving cars.”You don’t need to add “I think” or “I feel” or “I believe” to assert your opinions. You can chop out that wordy bit and simply assert your opinion. The reader already knows you think it, feel it, or believe it, because you wrote it! So, it’s redundant to add “I think/I feel/I believe.” All that addition would do is make the sentence wordy and make you sound less confident.

Well, one way you can do this is to write it in a neutral way by distancing yourself as a writer from it. For example, instead of: “I disagree that the young these days are too obsessed with fashion.” You can say: “The young these days are not too obsessed with fashion.” Oftentimes, when you do this, you would need to use passive sentences. This would mean that your word count would slightly increase but in return, you create a more unbiased feel to your writings. Your reader would feel that you are a somewhat objective writer, not clouded by your own biased or unfounded assumptions.
